ygData.subject: Re: What's Natural About Interactive Evolution (Warning: LONG message)
ygData.msgSnippet: Jeff, I went on too many tangents in my long post and thereby probably diluted my main point.  My main point was not about reaching any particular long term

Subject: Re: What's Natural About Interactive Evolution (Warning: LONG message)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=FXXi_goqMxORJ_95-1rQufNsGhOI5ctaOKBYASJVuj3j-bUm7GqW
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Jeff, I went on too many tangents in my long post and thereby 
probably dil=
uted my main point.  My main point was not about 
reaching any particular l=
ong term goal.  My point was that there is 
an analogy between the *process=
* of IEC and natural evolution.  
Remember that the original statement that=
 spawned this discussion 
was about IEC being more natural than TBE.  

Whe=
n you mention that IEC can no better reproduce an image than TBE 
(and that=
 you had trouble with your tiger), you are really making my 
point.  As soo=
n as you start setting a target (such as your tiger), 
you are in effect im=
posing TBE.  That is, an individual who starts 
playing with an IEC interfa=
ce from scratch who is intent on 
achieving a particular image will be disa=
ppointed because they are 
basically just doing TBE.  

However, Picbreeder=
 *as a whole* is not like that because it is not 
possible for there to be =
any overriding goal across the whole 
system.  That was why I emphasized th=
e fact that each individual in 
a chain of branches has a different set of =
motivations.  So 
someone's flower could end up the seed for a tiger that n=
obody was 
even looking for, even though you coudln't volitionally direct i=
t 
towards a tiger.  The target, in effect, is irrelevant. 

What's importa=
nt is the proliferation of jumping-off points.  And 
remember when I say "i=
mportant" all I'm talking about is importance 
toward making an anology wit=
h natural evolution, which similarly had 
no overriding goal and still has =
no overriding goal.  Remember what 
Dawkins said about how as soon as organ=
isms fill all the simple 
niches the only way to find a new niche is to com=
plexity (Jeff and I 
both saw Dawkins speak at GECCO).  I am not talking ab=
out importance 
towards any particular goal.  The side effect of the proces=
s I'm 
referring to is thus a kind of natural complexification.

That's why=
 I said, "Stop telling evolution what you want and let 
evolution show you =
what it can do."  Evolution can do a lot of 
amazing things if we just let =
it show us the paths it is disposed to 
take.  IEC is a way of exploring al=
l those paths with no particular 
purpose in mind (just like nature).

By t=
he way, you are right there have been a number of group-IEC 
systems in the=
 past.  It's good you pointed that out because it 
further clarifies what I=
'm meaning to get at.  What makes Picbreeder 
unique is that it is based en=
tirely on branching.  These past 
systems generally averaged the input of t=
heir users in one way or 
another, which tends to cause a washout effect.  =
What IEC should do 
to create a process like nature is proliferate jumping-=
off points, 
but an averaging system does the opposite- it only admits thin=
gs 
that are universally acceptable.

In fact, I can even demonstrate to yo=
u that it is not just the CPPN 
encoding that is allowing the impressive re=
sults on Picbreeder 
because one such project on the internet actually alre=
ady used 
DelphiNEAT-based encoding, but they implemented the collaboration=
 
with the traditional averaging method.  It's called the "Living 
Image Pr=
oject."  Look at the massive difference between what this 
system produces =
and Picbreeder (the Living Image Project has been 
going more than a year):=


http://w-shadow.com/li/

It's important to note that I don't mean to pick=
 on this project.  
It was one of the very few of its kind when it began an=
d was 
genuinely groundbreaking.  Its author deserves to be commended and 
=
its a lot of fun to follow.  Yet it does show that when you are 
collating =
a mass of opinions, you cannot go off in a myriad of 
different directions.=
  In fact, you can barely move anywhere at 
all.  Collaborative Genetic Art=
 installations of the past generally 
used this collating method (in one wa=
y or another) and produced 
images that look generally pretty, but don't sh=
ow any real 
progression.

Anyway, the main point is that the multi-user br=
anching-style of IEC 
(like Picbreeder) leads to a process that is more ana=
logous to 
natural evolution than TBE.  

ken

ugh TBE with

(if

efore pops up, so I

st is what's good

to natural evolution:  Natural

r the present candidates are

t its prolific creativity and its astounding

finitely.  Yes, I am claiming that it can do all

g-term targets

ed for doing what you *can* do.  And a good

letely arbitrary complex thing

pulation in the search space.

heir current strengths

ilateria 
(bilaterally-

umanity.  They

e eliminated.

did 
evolve

ven farther.  Can you imagine evaluating single

eir "human-ness?"  That would be silly.

e are doing in most evolutionary
> > experiments.  We do nothing to capture=

from

ultimate objectives.  So 
we

nteresting.

m 
Project, were

rom the

> point in x seconds is more fit"? It seems like you can =
equally

terals

>=

world

can we reward the intermediate serendipitous discoveries if we 
don't
> > k=
now what they should be?  The  answer is: Respect the fact that 
you
> > do=
n't know what they are.  Stop trying to *tell* evolution what 
it
> > can d=
o and let it *show* you what it can do.  When it shows you

ol, then keep that for later.  Keep everything with 
any

ter.  You never know what might be a foundation 
for the

t IEC

roo=

which ones would form a good foundation for something more

d many lineages didn't go anywhere), but because a lot of cool

re able to hang around, some of them happened to be good

s to the next big thing.  The issue was where the 
DNA

o next from where it is now.

t know what we want to 
evolve

that we have no

> > common goal at all.  We are all just trying=

Some of
> > us, when we see a cool path, take that path=
 a bit farther and a 
bit
> > farther still.  We keep all the intermediate =
stages around 
forever

stones.  Some 
happen
> > to be genuinely good foundations for future progr=
ess, like those

ould have seen 
that
> > coming?  If we had tried to evolve to them from th=
e start, we'd 
be

 this reason, what's going on in Picbreeder is really

> > doing some=
thing like natural evolution!  We may have some amazing

f that
